prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1313 Band 6 observations mosaic #1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal aims to detect CO (2-1) in NGC 1313; three more spectral windows are used to detect the continuum as well as other lines (methanol, CS 5-4, and H30alpha) in case they are present.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to resolve individual GMCs in this galaxy with masses of a few x 10^4 to 10^5 Msun; in studies of nearby resolved GMCs, such clouds have radii of ~10pc and velocity dispersions of a few km/s. With 0.85" (~19pc) spatial and 1.2 km/s velocity resolutions, we will resolve these individual clouds. Such clouds are expected to have CO 2-1 measurements of 20 mJy/beam, and a 5sigma detection requires an RMS of 4 mJy/beam. We measure our sensitivity over a 3 km/s bandwidth to increase signal to noise.

We will resolve the smallest velocity dispersion clouds (2-3 km/s) with 1-2 velocity channels and the largest complexes with up to ten velocity channels.
The radio recombination line will be wider, so we degrade the spectral resolution to 2.5 km/s for that spw to reduce the data rate.

With 0.85" angular resolution, we will resolve ~19pc scales at the distance of NGC 1313, allowing us to resolve the range of clouds we seek. We are also sensitive to emission on much larger scales (14"~300pc), which will allow us to recover the largest molecular complexes in the galaxy as well.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 7793 Band 6 observations mosaic #1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal aims to detect CO (2-1) in NGC 7793; three more spectral windows are used to detect the continuum as well as other lines (methanol, CS 5-4, and H30alpha) in case they are present.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to resolve individual GMCs in this galaxy with masses of a few x 10^4 to 10^5 Msun; in studies of nearby resolved GMCs, such clouds have radii of ~10pc and velocity dispersions of a few km/s. With 0.85" (=14pc) spatial and 1.2 km/s velocity resolutions, we will resolve these individual clouds. Such clouds are expected to have CO 2-1 measurements of 20 mJy/beam, and a 5sigma detection requires an RMS of 4 mJy/beam. We measure our sensitivity over a 3 km/s bandwidth to increase signal to noise.

We will resolve the smallest velocity dispersion clouds (2-3 km/s) with 1-2 velocity channels and the largest complexes with up to ten velocity channels.
The radio recombination line will be wider, so we degrade the spectral resolution to 2.5 km/s for that spw to reduce the data rate.

With 0.85" angular resolution, we will resolve 14pc scales in NGC 7793, allowing us to resolve the clouds in the mass range we seek. We are also sensitive to emission on much larger scales (11"~175pc), which will allow us to recover the largest molecular complexes in the galaxy as well.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1313 Band 6 observations mosaic #2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal aims to detect CO (2-1) in NGC 1313; three more spectral windows are used to detect the continuum as well as other lines (methanol, CS 5-4, and H30alpha) in case they are present.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to resolve individual GMCs in this galaxy with masses of a few x 10^4 to 10^5 Msun; in studies of nearby resolved GMCs, such clouds have radii of ~10pc and velocity dispersions of a few km/s. With 0.85" (~19pc) spatial and 1.2 km/s velocity resolutions, we will resolve these individual clouds. Such clouds are expected to have CO 2-1 measurements of 20 mJy/beam, and a 5sigma detection requires an RMS of 4 mJy/beam. We measure our sensitivity over a 3 km/s bandwidth to increase signal to noise.

We will resolve the smallest velocity dispersion clouds (2-3 km/s) with 1-2 velocity channels and the largest complexes with up to ten velocity channels.
The radio recombination line will be wider, so we degrade the spectral resolution to 2.5 km/s for that spw to reduce the data rate.

With 0.85" angular resolution, we will resolve 19pc scales in NGC 1313, allowing us to resolve clouds in the mass range we seek. We are also sensitive to emission on much larger scales (14"~300pc), which will allow us to recover the largest molecular complexes in the galaxy as well.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The impact of spiral structure and feedback from stellar populations on molecular clouds has broad-ranging implications for star formation in the present day universe. We propose to map the CO(2-1) emission on ~14-19 pc scales of two well-chosen disk galaxies, NGC1313 and NGC7793, which have similar masses, star formation rates and morphologies, but have very different spiral structures and widely different stellar cluster properties. These galaxies were observed as part of the HST Treasury program LEGUS (Legacy ExtraGalactic UV Survey), and we have derived the star formation histories, and cluster ages and masses. The unprecedented ALMA/LEGUS synergy will provide a comprehensive investigation of star formation in spiral galaxies by connecting the resolved molecular properties with detailed stellar population information. Specific issues to be addressed include: the timescales over which star formation occurs in molecular clouds, the lifetimes of clouds, and the role of star formation in the gas turbulence. We will compare our results with our predictions from simulations, to guide next-generation models of star formation and galaxy evolution.
